Definition: In this task, you are given a public comment from online platforms. You are expected to classify the comment into two classes: toxic and non-toxic. Toxicity is defiend as anything that is rude, disrespectful, or unreasonable that would make someone want to leave a converation.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: i am just sorry that khadr didnt get a bullet in the head before he blew the head off that innocent father because his islamic boogie skywizard told him to.
Positive Examples.explanation: This is a toxic comment because it advocates acts of violence.
This is a non-toxic comment because it is not rude or desrespectful.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: "racism" -appears to be the only card in your deck!?
Negative Examples.explanation: This should be non-toxic because the comment only speaks of racism but does not disrespect any race.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: Fat ass, go eat another do-nut.
Negative Examples.explanation: This should be toxic because it disrespects the people that are overweight.

Comment: Hawaii, like the nation as a whole, desperately needs a decent Republican party that hews to its progressive founding principles - the party that championed the rights of slaves, broke up the corporate monopolies, created the EPA and advocated for universal health care. A party that Lincoln, Teddy Roosevelt or even, dare I say it, Richard Nixon could be proud of.  You can be all those things and still advocate for a bootstrapping, small government, low tax agenda. Hawaii WOULD be better if those arguments were cogently made in our legislature.  But the GOP of today is abject in its subservience to corporate and theocratic interests, spiteful in its embrace of racism and misogyny, and wicked in its willful rejection of science – wicked because in refusing to act on climate change it threatens all humanity.  There are progressive Republicans like Rep. Cynthia Thielen, but the recent history has been that the tea baggers who run the Hawaii GOP have been chasing decent Republicans away.

Comment: I am sorry, but this article by an uninformed author is another in the narrative  demanding that sexual assault investigations be slanted so all women are instantly granted 'victim' status, and that the subject of the complaint,  usually men are 'suspects', regardless of the credibility of the complaint. 

Further, contrary to what the writer states, it is not the job of the police to 'investigate and charge.'   Rather, it is the job of the police to investigate and determine the exact circumstances, and if warranted, to recommend the charges to Crown Counsel.  (In BC this is the process.)

It is also necessary for the police to interview the complainant to establish a; the identity of the alleged perpetrator, b; where this took place, c; is there physical evidence at the scene or on the person of the complaint, d; witnesses, and e; most important of all, ensure  it was clearly non-consensual.

Unless these facts are determined, the courts will not convict anyone.  Nor should they.

Comment: Here's an irony: Many believe keeping interest rates low will make homes more affordable when the opposite is true--Fed interest rates that are set too low for too long will have a tremendous impact on the creation of housing bubbles which have led to an unprecedented increase in housing prices across the U.S. starting in 1997. Thus it could be argued that the Fed would do better to adhere closely to the Taylor rule in their setting of the nominal interest rate. While we can't say for sure if we're in a housing bubble, one way to gauge the real value of housing is to compare it with long-term inflation. U.S. median family home prices are currently overvalued at around 30% above the long-term inflationary trend. This coupled with the fed funds rate near the 1% low which former Fed chairman Allan Greenspan set it, which triggered the housing bubble of 2005, could very well mean we're in the thick of another housing bubble. Do I hear trillion dollar government bailout of the big banks?

Comment: John,
But the lawsuit does not allege Chlorpyrifos use or misuse, correct? Why lump that insecticide with the herbicides the lawsuit lists? 

I think of it like this... when I am using a miter saw to cut wood at work, I wear safety glasses, gloves, ear protection and have a working knowledge of the saw and how to use it right through training and experience. But I don't complain and file a lawsuit if my boss doesn't train me on an arc welder that I am not using, but it might be used in the next room over in the shop. And I don't file a lawsuit when my boss doesn't give me leather gauntlets and a welding face shield for my miter saw if I am not using the welder or in the vicinity of the welder.

I will be waiting to see the details of the case, not just the allegations! Because these are very serious allegations!

Comment: Christian realism is a foreign policy perspective that originated with Reinhold Niebuhr, the famous moral theologian and public intellectual who was really a titanic figure on the American scene from the 1930s into the 1960s. The essence of Christian realism—which is very much at odds with anything that smacks of utopianism—is to appreciate that there is evil in the world to which we must respond but also to appreciate that our own motives are likely to be less pure than we may fancy them to be. It’s not simply that the motives of the other guys are suspect but we ourselves should always be mindful of the extent to which our own motives [may] be subject to question.
Andrew Bacevich

Comment: The guys camped out on the Punchbowl off, they are on State property and the city has to move on problems one at a time. There is no magic bullet to solve all of them. If HPD had to arrest all the homeless on their beats, there would be no police officers left to take care of the other problems. There aren't enough detention facilities to house them. And courts would be backed up. I am only citing things that were done in the past. There were some wins, geographical restrictions was great for me as a watch commander in China town. Yup moved problem but I was also realistic about what the police department  and my officers could do. Restrictions was a temporary solution but it brought together the Chinatown Neighborhood board, the Honolulu Prosecutors, and the Courts, community policing. By the way thanks for being part of community policing, sounds like you were part of a neighborhood watch program. If you have no soultions going forward, maybe we need to look back and see what worked.

something to look to and learn from.  Youth will always take itself very seriously so no

"Your catastrophic major medical policy would be covering your wife's costs"

You'd think that, but in Colorado we're on a tort-based system. While our auto insurance picked up the initial $5K, it's been significantly out of pocket for us since.

My kids are now recovered (credit their young bodies), but since the accident my wife suffers from constant jaw-pain, neck-pain, headache, and facial numbness (she can't feel half her face).

Due to the nature of her injuries, much of her treatment, such as physical therapy, is going uncovered by our insurance. For example, United deemed her jaw pain to be TMD, and swiftly cut off payments to the jaw specialist. To be fair, other things, like neurologist appts (and the imaging they've ordered) *have* been covered.

Comment: The key to having no stress over tipping is to select the country well. There are many places where tipping is frowned upon or just not the thing. Vacation in these places and the money you save from not having to tip all the time more than makes up for the higher initial cost. When you visit the developing world, remember you are taking on the risk of being there (terrorism, disease, crime) and there is always somebody making a big profit from your presence (resort owner, hotel owner etc.). Don't plague yourself with guilt about tips: if the elite choose to leave their people poor, that is not your problem. 

It is a Canadian arrogance to think you will right the world's wrongs by generously tipping. 

Other options include staying in self-catering places, renting condos, camping, using a camper van etc. 

Buy a recipe book before hand and in many places you could cook a better meal than any restaurant would!

Comment: Having reviewed the content of the article, I can see the potential drawback of this product  offering. -However- It has been a useful product for me. A Schedule 'A' bank offered me a 'HELC' after I put down $50K to purchase a $ 177K home purchase at 3.7%  in '2010'; interest only payments if I wanted. I chose principal and interest payments. -Then- In '2015' it was suggested that I take out a mortgage for the residual amount owing on the HELC at 2.24% ; continue paying principal and interest, and save approximately $16 K in interest . -Now- I was informed that I could borrow against the increasing HELC credit portion available but at 3.7% interest rate. -Although- The rate was better than a unsecured/ secured L/C, I have not now nor ever intend to do so. -And- When the mortgage comes up for renewal in '2018', if the rate is not better than 2.24%; i.e. if the rates go up, I can always convert it back to the HELC at the fixed at 3.7% at no cost. No problem  in my case that I can see.

Comment: In this story the reporters imply there is something wrong with the way police classify reports of sexual assault that is in some way harmful to the victims. To me that is the fake news element of this story. 

This story is all about how some cases are classified. Unfounded may be a catchall for those cases where there is no possibility of a successful prosecution. This may be beneficial to the victims since it does not identify why the cases are so classified, thereby protecting the victim from scrutiny.

I foresee as a result of this story that the police may redefine unfounded claims as one or more of the following categories;

-insufficient evidence
-inconclusive evidence
-questionable evidence
-victim unwillingness/inability to provide evidence

Will this be better? I doubt it.

Whatever they do the results will likely not lead to any more charges or convictions. For that to happen laws must be changed to make offenders guilty until proven innocent.

Comment: And then there is hearsay in court, courtesy of FindLaw » Learn About The Law » Criminal Law » Criminal Procedure » "Hearsay" Evidence:
---
"The rule against hearsay is deceptively simple and full of exceptions. Hearsay is an out of court statement, made in court, to prove the truth of the matter asserted. In other words, hearsay is evidence of a statement that was made other than by a witness while testifying at the hearing in question and that is offered to prove the truth of the matter stated. For example, Witness A in a murder trial claimed on the stand: "Witness B (the "declarant") told me that the defendant killed the victim." The definition of hearsay is not too difficult to understand. But the matter can become very confusing when one considers all of the many exceptions to the general rule against hearsay..."
----

Comment: The Sioux, including Sitting Bull and Red Cloud accepted the terms of the Treaty of 1868 which placed the northern boundary at the 46th parallel and the Missouri River. Well south of the area of the pipeline. In 1873 an executive order was enacted that moved the border north to the Cannon Ball River, again well south of the pipeline location. The Sioux have accepted the treaty terms for that last 148 years. I would say that kind of trumps your argument, (pun intended). The treaty ;problems are with the Treaty of 1877 that was done without the consent of the Sioux as required by the Treaty  of 1868. It also broke up the one big reservation into several smaller reservations and took away the Black Hills, but the Sioux, rightfully, have never accepted the Treaty of 1877. I think they never should accept the Treaty of 1877. However, in every case, the northern boundary is the Cannon Ball River, still well south of the pipeline due to an executive order in 1873 moving the boundary north.

Comment: All well and good. The meat industry is also one of the main drivers of climate change. Laudato Si does not even mention it. Would be good to see some action from Catholic groups on that front. It's not only about fossil fuels.  The meat industry is the world's largest polluter (responsible for 51% of greenhouse gases, according to some reports). The leading cause of rainforest destruction, species extinction, ocean dead zones and water pollution is not fossil fuels, but raising animals for food. "Livestock" produce more greenhouse gases than all the world's cars, trucks, boats, planes and trains combined. To stop climate change we need trees, but 90% of Amazon destruction is for animal agriculture. 45% of earth's ice-free land is occupied by animal agriculture, with free-living animals being squeezed out of their habitat all the time. 30% of all water consumed is for animal agriculture. Almost 50% of the world's grain is fed to "livestock," yet a billion people go hungry every day.

Comment: Van Brocklin is right.  Right on the law, and right in thinking that encouraging refractory reactions to arrest could endanger both citizens and officers. Does Van Brocklin think all this has nothing to do with why Americans, especially minority and poor5 Americans, feel the police are an occupying force without moral legitimacy?

Comment: Those of us facing this law and similar ones across the country must not stand by and let campus carry become our new reality. If we accept armed campuses as inevitable, then we are adapting our way toward the demise of the public university in America. We already endure funding cuts, crumbling infrastructure, the adjunctification of teaching, assaults on academic freedom and now … assault rifles in our classrooms? If we accept this latest legislative attack, we risk becoming the proverbial frog who is slowly boiled alive. Although recent experiments refute the scientific veracity of this tale, it is nonetheless an apt metaphor for where the modern public institution finds itself -- in hot water that’s getting hotter. Guns on campuses make the vulnerable even more vulnerable, argues Philip Nel. They uphold established systems of power: white supremacy, patriarchy and the privilege of the tenured.

Comment: As others have pointed out, you could have literally hundreds of cyclists (or thousands of pedestrians) using a roadway before you did as much damage as a single car. The shift wasn't merely a change in volume, but towards a form of transportation that demanded, by its nature, near-exclusive use of the right-of-way; needed unprecedented investments in infrastructure to be viable; and which, as mentioned, resulted in ballooning maintenance costs.

Also, I think you underestimate the volume of traffic before the advent of cars. Congestion was an urban issue long before the Industrial Revolution. Urbanization pre-automobile made it worse. A busy NYC street in 1903, for instance, likely contained more people than could fit on a modern roadway, since single-occupancy vehicles make inefficient use of space.

The bottom line is cars cost the public in unique ways; gas taxes and motor vehicle fees were initiated in a conscious acknowledgment of that. Bikes weren't omitted as an oversight.

Comment: Nobody - because I said nothing about ideas being tolerable. I spoke of ideas being tolerANT or not. And that is an extremely easy thing to determine. Your idea is tolerant if, and only if, part of that idea is that you have to tolerate me and my ideas. It's a very simple quod-pro-quo calculation. I must tolerate your views even if I disagree with them - as long as you do the same for me. If your view is that I should be cut into tiny little pieces and fed to the dogs, I'm not obligated to tolerate that view. If your view is that I should not be allowed to express my views - then I'm not obligated to tolerate that view and I am justified to prevent you expressing it so that all the many other views can remain safe to express.

Comment: You are right, the Church did not deal with this matter in a comprehensive way. I don't think there is a single reason for this. 

Although child sexual abuse (CSA) is and has been a widespread phenomenon both culturally and historically, civil society did not deal with it comprehensively until very recently either. 

The age to marry in the RCC according to CCL has been 14 for the longest time. So sexual contact with people fifteen and up could have been explained away as sexual misconduct/sin, and not abuse, that could be fixed by spiritual means (confession, prayer, etc). Remember,  the overwhelming cases of abuse involved postpubertal individuals.

Every institution has a basic reflex to protect itself. Add to this the fear and disdain of scandal in the RCC, and the high regard for the secrecy of the confessional, and you have a strong incentive to keep things private or secret.

These are just a few reasons, but none of this justifies anything. But it is worth considering them.

Comment: One would assume that in a legitimately objective legal system the courts (and especially a Supreme Court) must permit input from all relevant stakeholders. By deselecting LGBTQ intervenors in a case where LGBTQ rights and interests are fundamental to the matter at hand, the SCC's original position failed the test of objectivity. Imagine if the SCC were to hear and rule on an appeal application about a pipeline in northern Canada after deselecting intervenors representing aboriginal interests. It just wouldn't happen. And it shouldn't happen, just as it shouldn't in a case where LGBTQ interests as well as the legitimate right of LGBTQ citizens/residents to be protected from discrimination are at stake. This is not about special interests. It's about the right of people from a historically oppressed community to be able to protect themselves from discrimination. To shut them out of the process would have transformed the SCC into little more than a kangaroo court.

Comment: This report really hits home for me. The real issue is that both young and old use their phone when they are driving or walking in public. These individuals believe that they can handle it. Reality hits when an accident occurs. Reality hit for me in 2008: my 11-year old was walking home from school - half-way through a crosswalk with the light still green and not on his phone - and he was hit by a large SUV that ran a red light. The driver was a mother who was on her phone and her kids were in the back seat. From police report, my son was thrown 140 feet. He survived. The woman's license was suspended in lieu of imprisonment. Almost 9 years later, my son is still piecing together his life. His little sister said it best: you can add up the medical bills and missing days from school, but you cannot bring back his fun-loving spirit; our family life was shattered. Is it worth it? Is it about your entitlement to your phone? Or is it more?

Comment: Interesting, isn't it, how when a dialogue with an anti-feminist proceeds long enough, the chauvinist's argument boils down to wanting to re-make all women into his image of his sainted mother?

A curious byproduct of patriarchy is this collective tendency to both demonize and idealize motherhood.  Psychological maturity is to resist this tendency.

We encourage them to get to know various healthcare options so that they know which one of them can provide the best benefits without hurting their finances. Comment: Nope.  Jesus missed the ["institution of a priesthood"] by at least a century, or more.  You going need to search a long time to find scriptural basis in the NT for your assertion.  

The authorship of Hebrews is uncertain - Eusebius, the Greek historian and polemicist of Christianity (314 AD) had his doubts about Paul's authorship .  But we do know that it was written most likely in Rome - therefore it presents a christology that is a backwards look in time.

Scholars believe the Book of Hebrews - very polished and eloquent - was written for Jewish Christians.  Its purpose was to exhort Christians to persevere in the face of persecution. The theme of the epistle is the doctrine of the person of Christ and his role as mediator between God and humanity - which eventually did become a major tenet in Christianity's priesthood cult.

Comment: CO2 reflects sunlight and does indeed cool the planet.  However, the total amount of CO2 released by volcanoes averages about .26 gigatons per year, compared with 32 gigatons per year by human activity worldwide (US Energy Information Administration, for the year 2012).  Also, it is a major factor in ocean acidification.  The pH has fallen by .1 unit over the last few hundred years, which is about 30 percent more acidic.  By the end of this century, it will be nearly 150% more acidic, which will affect the entire food chain upon which about a billion people depend on for their livelihood and food (NOAA, et al).  Massive amounts of CO2 in the atmosphere is not our friend.

Comment: There are many examples of technological disruptors who succeeded to push "old-line" incumbents out far faster than investors anticipated or the incumbents could adapt. Here are a few...
- In 2008, Blockbuster CEO Jim Keyes told the Motley Fool that Netflix "isn't even on the radar screen in terms of competition". Just 2 years later, Blockbuster filed for bankruptcy.
- In 2006, Palm CEO Ed Colligan said of the newly announce iPhone "They’re not going to just walk in." Just 2 years later, Palm stopped making PDAs.
- In 2011, Nintendo president Reggie Fils-Aime dismissed mobile games. Just 4 years later, mobile game revenue overtook console game revenue.
- In 1977, DEC founder Ken Olsen said "There is no reason anyone would want a computer in their home,". Just 4 years later, IBM introduced the PC. Once the 2nd largest computer company in the world, DEC is now a footnote.

Comment: You want proof? I switched to being a private investor this year. Started selling my funds at the end of January: put more than 1/2 the money in high interest savings and term deposits and invested the rest in equities, starting in May. I had absolutely no experience when I started. Just did a whole lot of reading and talked to people who've been investing for years. Invested mainly in blue chips. For fun, I check the performance of my old funds on a daily basis. Here's where things stand today, 4 months after taking the plunge: 1) my old TFSA fund, 1.33% YTD; my new TFSA, 6.51%; 2) my old RRSP fund, 0.76 % YTD; I have two new RRSPs: one in a savings account at @ 2.10%, the other invested in the market is at 3.21%: the plan is to invest more in equities as I gain more experience; 3) my old RRIF fund is at minus 0.30% YTD; my new RRIF is earning 2.40%. So, in four months, and with no experience, my investments are doing better than with an advisor. Draw your own conclusions...

Comment: It seems to me that certain senior Liberals are more concerned about pandering to the wishes of insurance industry lobbyists on Bill S-201 than they are about protecting the interests of Canadians and the Charter rights of individuals. The US, UK, all other G7 countries and UNESCO already prohibit genetic discrimination. No insurance companies have gone bankrupt as a result. 

Approximately 91% of Canadians polled feel that insurance companies should not be allowed access to their genetic information for an insurance assessment. Further, 90% of Canadians opposed the notion that employers should have access to the genetic information of workers or job applicants.

We all know that corporations control our MPs through their 'political donations', but it's a little much to have the Prime Minister so cravenly demonstrating where his allegiance lies. Can he not do the right thing for a change? Protect our individual privacy and honour Liberal campaign promises!

Comment: Dear Abby is missing the point when he says file it under 'her problems'. Fine advice if it was just the sister at risk. But having co-signed a mortgage, the mother must now maintain the house and the payments in order to avoid a default and a possible 'joint and several' claim against her and her hubby. 

Sadly there's no shortage of parents who have either refused to kick their offspring out of the nest or, worse still, put their own finances in jeopardy by helping them buy their own nest. Having not taught their daughter accountability and respect, she is unable to demand it of others. 

As to what advice to give, that would depend on whether the parents - even at this late stage - are prepared to grow a spine. If the mother is also half-owner of the house, she could insist on selling it off. It's more likely though that she owns nothing but the debt, in which case I would predict this will end badly for everyone - except of course the scum boyfriend.

Comment: Much of Canada's "top talent" moves to California which also has high taxation and a cost of living worst than Ontario!

It's really about career growth and job density...

Career growth: Many Fortune 500 corporations have satellite offices in Canada, but whether you're a manager or an engineer, you'll hit a glass ceiling. You have to work in their head offices to climb the corporate ladder or work on their core projects.

Job density: In Silicon Valley specifically, there are so many major corporations in close proximity, if one lays you off, you can move to their competitor down the street. In Canada, our tech industry is more spread out, so switching jobs often means uprooting your family and moving to another city.

Comment: Single-payer healthcare in California? The annual cost was: $400 billion. Of that, $200 billion would come from existing federal, state and local funding for healthcare. The remaining $200 billion would have to be raised from higher taxes. The plan of universal healthcare activists is to convince President Trump and the Republican-controlled Congress to transfer all the Medi-Cal billions to help leftist California finance a single-payer system, something they’d fear and deride as socialized medicine. The committee analysis assumed a 15% payroll tax on income. This in a state that already suffers from the highest income tax rates in the nation. But if all this happened, there’d still be between $50 billion and $100 billion in new money needed to fund a single-payer healthcare system. There’d be no premiums, co-pays or deductibles — and therefore no self controls. So who knows how steep new medical costs would climb?

By George SkeltonContact Reporter
Capitol Journal California

Comment: This project in sustainable living is inspiring, but creating an urban culture to support it is another matter. Let's envision a city that rewards pilot projects like these that reduce their household carbon costs.

St. Justin Martyr knew Greek philosophy very well, and the philosophical schools all hold "reason," "logos," in high regard in one way or another (it becomes an especially important technical term among the Stoics), Plato being the first to make a direct association between human beings' mental faculties and the transcendent. Rufinus quotes one of the Desert Fathers he interviewed, giving an excellent Platonic answer to a question about the origin of the virtues: "The mother of all the virtues is diákrisis," that word meaning discernment, discretion, and discrimination, all at once.

Comment: ""It would be different pools under different rules," said one senior health policy source..."

Literally the definition of how every other type of insurance works. You select the coverage you determine you need based on your own calculated risk of possible but unlikely events you cannot (or do not want to) realistically save to cover, and are pooled with other similarly situated persons (based on the insurer's actuarial data) to pay costs directly related to the calculated risk they take that you or a significant number of fellow poolees might actually need to use the plan.  If you want broader coverage, you are free to pay for more.

Comment: I don't believe God's commandments are barriers, limiting "breathing room", or any of God's commandments for that matter. They free us nicely.
His commandments help us to grow in holiness toward Him faster with less injury to ourselves and more importantly less injury to others.
God is loving and forgiving, but He knows how we operate..how our appetites and passions can attain dominion, how our intellect can get co-opted by our emotions, making it harder to see the truth. Failing to accept that there is a truth that we must use our whole life to strive toward leads us down false paths of happiness: abortion, divorce, drugs, bad use of our sexual gifts, prideful pursuit of professional career, crime, selfishness. These are lies that we fall into because we've not accepted His truth, fully & with abandonment.
Even how God wants us to take care of the poor has to be done in the right way, for the right reason; otherwise it too can become corrupted. It too can turn into a prideful pursuit.

Comment: Not exactly, but somewhat true.  The placebo effect is real and can be amazing, but first off it doesn't "quite often work", but it sometimes works.  Also, when it works it often isn't long lasting.  The placebo effect can have a real change in peoples'mental well being (hence feeling better) but there is little to no real evidence that there is any reversal in disease progression.  It can be noted though that a better mental state typically means less stress, and less stress can help bodies fight infections and slow the progression of some diseases.

Comment: It shouldn’t be surprising that Vladimir Putin would want to interfere in US politics to advance Russia’s foreign policy goals – from curtailing Nato to ending sanctions over the conflict in Ukraine and preserving Bashar Assad’s regime in Syria. 

But what should surprise and disturb is that the Republican party is so vulnerable to Russian interference. The Republican party, traditionally associated with a hawkish stance toward Moscow, threw its support behind a presidential candidate who openly called on Russia to hack his opponent’s campaign.

Majority leader Mitch McConnell told Obama and leading Democrats that he would regard any effort to release evidence of Russian interference before the election as partisan. In other words, he put his own party’s interest in electing Trump ahead of the national interest.

Comment: Pepe LePew,
The State of Alaska assumed the Child Protection Services for Alaska Natives because Alaska was put under PL280, with five other states. Tribes had no say in the matter.

What PL280 is : "Public Law 280 is a federal statute enacted by Congress in 1953. It enabled states to assume criminal, as well as civil, jurisdiction in matters involving Indians as litigants on reservation land. Previous to the enactment of Public Law 280, these matters were dealt with in either tribal and/or federal court."

States : "Enumerated in Public Law 280 were six states which were obligated to assume jurisdiction from the outset of the law: Alaska, California, Minnesota, Nebraska, Oregon, and Wisconsin. States that have assumed at least some jurisdiction since the enactment of Public Law 280 include: Nevada, South Dakota, Washington, Florida, Idaho, Montana, North Dakota, Arizona, Iowa, and Utah." (Note: Metlakatla in Alaska retained rights)

*States can opt out of PL280.
*ICWA 1978 All states

Comment: good lord. The lack of logic of some of you is nothing less than amazing. 
1) when you buy a COMPUTER, it has a CPU in it. Some are rated at say 2.0 ghz, and others at 3.0 ghz. These are the EXACT SAME CPU. The difference is that the 3.0 rated was fully tested at 3.0 ghz and work at it. OTOH, the 2.0 was tested at 2.0 and not tested at 3.0. Yet, 99% of them will run at 3.0 JUST FINE. But you paid say $150 for the 2.0 OR you would have paid $500 for the 3.0. What is difference? Just the speed at which they ran the EXACT SAME TEST. 
This is true on YOUR PHONE. On any laptop, etc.  How do you obtain the faster speed? By changing the software. This is just 1 example of this. 

2) Tesla sold you a car with a set amount of charge capabilities. At the same time, they TOLD YOU that at any time, if you want, you can pay extra and the software will upgrade it. Comment: The problem is that Canada's tax system was designed when the norm was one family member working until he was 65, spending 5 years enjoying his retirement, and dropping dead at 70, at a time when there were many working people and few retirees to support, except for widows who got by on very little.  (My grandmother thought she was in clover when she got OAS and Guaranteed income supplement) 
Now, people's needs. expectations, and life span have increased almost exponentially. and by the time the baby boomers all retire, there is no way that the workers will be able to support them/us in the style to which we've become accustomed. 
At the same time, some have become enamoured of the idea that they're special and shouldn't pay tax, and there are aggressive tax planners who make a living trying to make it so.
Our tax system needs to change.  This is one small start.

Comment: Can we at least legislate that fires be put out when they are found? The Chetco Bar fire, now pushing 300 square miles, was originally found at one-quarter acre. A decision was made to allow it to burn, an obvious bad call.

Notice that the worst fires in CA manage to get to ten to fifteen square miles, and often much, much smaller, before they are not just contained but extinguished. This valuing of structures over lungs isn't good public policy, at least for those of us with lungs.

Comment: "Logging will transfer vast amounts of carbon from the forest to the atmosphere ..."  Not necessarily. When you cut down a tree, you eliminate it's ability to store carbon in the future, but the products made from those trees still store that carbon ... it's locked up in the wood product. A tree that falls and rots stores some carbon in the soil, but most is released to the atmosphere. When trees operate in a system, forests are great carbon sinks, no doubt, but I think you're overestimating the value of a small patch of trees here that are not part of a larger forest system ... trees that are apparently getting knocked down by storms and probably rotting, based on other comments here. You'll get nearly as much carbon storage cutting and replanting as you will leaving them to rot in such a small clump.

Comment: It's sad to read the many negative comments about teacher's salaries and benefits, especially considering 35 plus students per class. Unfortunately, it's not unusual, in all parts of the country.  I was in high school teaching for four years in California. Left as soon as I could, partly for the lack of support from local school board and community.  Fortunately, the National Science Foundation paid me to get my M.S. degree in Chemistry with all fees covered. I quickly moved on to an outstanding community college at one of the highest paying colleges in the country.  The respect from community, administration, and students was the difference between night and day.  

By having decent salaries and benefits, Eugene is able to attract the better teachers from all parts of the country.  Consider this (baby sitting wages): $10 an hour per student times 35 students equals $350 per class.  Five classes at $1750 a day times 190 days equals $332,500 per year.  $103,000 a year is a bargain!

Comment: Many European states really should acknowledge the need for greater federalism.  The monarchic age in European history saw kings cobble together vastly disparate holdings with little regard for the local populations.  Many of those imperial states disintegrated in the 20th century (e.g, Austria-Hungary, an enormous union of a dozen or more major ethnic groups with nothing in common beyond that the Habsburgs had managed to acquire their land at some point), but others didn't, and the advent of greater democracy didn't obviate the centralizing, dominant culture of the central state.  I don't think Catalonia has any issues that couldn't be addressed to most people's satisfaction through devolved constitutional status.

Comment: A firm justification for laws limiting the freedom of citizens is the protection of others who might be adversely affected.  In the case of alcohol, there is a potential danger of drunken driving and other acts committed under the influence.  Good laws do not limit individual freedom unless it significantly advances the safety or rights of the general population.  In the present instance, the purchase and use of cigarettes by the younger population does not significantly impact the safety or rights of the general population.  Therefore this restriction on freedom does not conform to good democratic practice.  The dangers of second hand smoke are addressed by other laws prohibiting smoking in various places.  This law represents only the limitation of individual freedom because of the opinions and preferences of others.  In a free society, limitations on freedom should be avoided except when absolutely necessary.

Comment: The dams are not being overtopped at this point.  They're releasing a controlled amount through the gates and an additional amount is now going over the spillways.  Each dam has concrete-covered spillways located at the high ends of the basins that are several feet below the top of the earthen portion.  So far, Barker and Addicks are doing what they're designed to do.  That having been said, neither has ever held the amount of water currently behind the dams and the pressure behind them undoubtedly concerns authorities.  Agree that actual overtopping or failure of either one would do untold additional damage from the west side of Houston through downtown.

Comment: The Globe article headline is "Doctors warn thousands could leave for U.S. over new federal tax hikes".  This is a misstatement.  There are no "new taxes"  for doctors. It appears some doctors have discovered a loophole to avoid the existing taxes by multiple use  of a small business rate.  The government is closing the loophole, so the doctors now have to pay what they should have done all along, in common with most other Canadians.

I find it unbelievable that many doctors would want to move to the USA because they were denied a loophole in their taxes.  This would imply that these doctors have no commitment to Canada or our way of life, and few if any family ties to keep them here.  Does the Globe really have evidence that many doctors would move, or is it just an imaginary claim in order to create more sensational articles?

Comment: The economics of movie-making now encourage mindless entertainment which does not depend on shared cultural references. 

There is more money to be made with movies that sell globally, i.e. the lowest common denominator, than with complex, introspective, chatty movies that depend on people "getting"  the cultural subtleties.

I am all for people watching excellent movies from a variety of cultures, but it isn't any more likely for most people here than in India or China or elsewhere. Most people will watch movies they "get", not ones that are incomprehensible to them. That is why a shared culture is the sine qua none for a thriving quality cinema, literature, etc.

Comment: Cracked column basalt and a transition forest that goes from oak savannah to rain forest conifer to rain shadow pine to oak savannah to high desert.   The slides will be released by water freezing and expanding,  and then thawing,  and rain lubricating the now loosened rocks.   Freezing is one of the important factors.  And rain on frozen ground can be a flash flood event.

Dead,  burned trees,  rot at the mean annual winter  snow level,  be that one foot   or four or more.  You can actually accurately guess the mean annual winter snow level by the height of the stumps from  blowdown in a burn area.  The real danger over time will be snag toboggans rocketing towards the railroad and freeway.....or the back of your home.  

Salvage log or not (that area is mostly helicopter logging ground),  the dead trees will fall.  The issue is who gets to control the aftermath.  My life experience includes fire watch duties,  and when the afternoon humidity dropped,  trees fell.  Wet rot dried out.

Comment: Several years ago, when using a computer with backup UPS power, the gauge
on the unit said the local utility (Chugach) was supplying 132 Volts... 

Since my 'uninterruptable power supply' with automatic voltage regulation on thoroughput was handling the irregularity with ease, I thought to call the dispatch line at Chugach; to inform them directly.

To be able to call the actual power experts, saves a lot of time and grief. I was able to
suggest that perhaps at an earlier maintenance interval, someone may have tested the system and had not set it back to the usual & customary output. I was spot-on; my suspicions confirmed.

(Not the first time I'd found an issue, or diagnosed a problem, as end-user Chugach customer.)

Most the people working there at desks have no idea what I've said, in regard to odd power effects, from a distance outside the city. They live a different life; many more outages, reasons, longer failures due to weather, trees, avalanches, etc. outside town. Such fun ;)

Comment: Scott:  You mention "current" abuse.  Would you be good enough to expand on your contention.  I presume you're referencing a possible initiative which might lead to a further initiativve to control aerial spraying of herbicides.  If, indeed, that is your concern, fine, you should be addressing that particular issue, not supporting an "end run" effort which would give the Board veto power over all initiatives which Lane County voters have worked hard to, and have in fact, qualified for the ballot.  May I again state: The initiative process comes with "built-in" checks to "weed out" frivolous measures.  First, it requires a significant number of petition signatures to qualify for the ballot.  Secondly, it requires a majority of voters to support its adoption. Thirdly, it,like all ordinances, would be subject to judicial review.  At each step proponents must make a convincing argument that the measure is a) constitutional and b) desirable.  This process is called DEMOCRACY.

Comment: MC, First, this site purports to use some mix of "NEA, job survey and private data" to come up with their numbers. In their own words, it's "tricky business". Second, the numbers aren't actual salaries, but are a "comfort index" which tries to give a weighted metric vis a vis cost of living(which can vary a lot within states). Hardly "hard data" to make a policy decision off of, but perhaps useful for rookie teachers looking for work, maybe.  Just having starting and average salaries doesn't tell you the whole story. Averages can be skewed by very  high/low earners, a more useful number is median salary. And again, it doesn't address the total compensation issue, or any other factors that are involved that make one state's situation different from anothers. Still waiting for that comprehensive study to be dug up. I think I'll be waiting a while.

Comment: " ..putting money into the preservation of native languages would be a concrete gesture that could produce equally concrete benefits..."

Well - the money would be appreciated and spent by the language police - but guaranteed without any permanent benefit to the FN - merely preserving isolation and hopeless life style of frustration.

Being multilingual and having been around the globe more often than I wish to count - my experience:
- English is the language of busines, technology, logistics, documentation .... No matter whether you are in China, Japan, Europe .....
- Translation beyond the superficial - involving deep cultural context - is tricky, very expensive and of limited availability. Technical translation is not possible for languages that have not evolved in terms of the Industrial; Revolution and its consequences.
- For any language group to survive requires a critical mass of speakers and their economic independence. My guess would be a minimum of 100 Million + population.

Comment: "You are required to have car insurance to drive on our public roads."

===

Wrong. You are required to have LIABILITY insurance as a condition of being granted a driver's license. This protects other motorists and your own assets. (Insurance on the vehicle is usually a condition of borrowing the money to buy the car. This protects the lien holder, no one else, although it's prudent to protect your own assets.) 

To apply the parallel to health coverage, you would require insurance as a condition of being alive. This is unique in the entire economy. (Never mind that you have the option of paying for your health care by numerous other means.)

Huge distinction.

While it's a wise purchase -- like auto or homeowners insurance -- health insurance doesn't necessarily protect anyone else. If your interest is enforcing responsibility -- as defined by whom, by the way? -- one is simply liable for his own bills. That requires no mandate or enforcement by the state over a private transaction.

Comment: Oh.  Let me clarify.  I was talking about for the penalty.  I don't think that people should be forced as they are now to pay for insurance, but if they get sick and have to go to the Medicare option, they should have to pay a penalty for getting the coverage.  But this should only apply to those who make above x% of the poverty level, so the poor aren't being penalized.  I would also only expand Medicare to cover the poor with certain chronic conditions and disabilities (including mental and addictions), children, and the working poor or those on unemployment. Comment: A rather delayed response. Imagine that a retailer sells chicken for R 30/kg. The retailer has an invoice price for that chicken of R 25/kg meaning a R 5 GP. Written into the supply agreement is that the chicken supplier will pay for various marketing expenses via rebates, shelf fees etc. which costs the supplier R 5/kg.  The chicken supplier nets R 20/kg. If the retailer paid for all the marketing costs themselves the chicken supplier still gets R 20/kg, the retailer still sells the chicken for R 30/kg but the retailer GP is now R 10/kg. This changes the way the retailers books are presented.

Comment: The CDC reports that there are about 20 million cases of Norovirus in the U.S. every year, a large fraction of them from restaurants.  "Infected food workers are frequently the source of these outbreaks, often by touching ready-to-eat foods, such as raw fruits and vegetables, with their bare hands before serving them."  Using gloves is no panacea, true, but it will help.  What would help even more would be a requirement that food workers be given paid sick leave.  Food workers are generally poorly paid as it is, and it is a hardship for them to take off from work when they are ill, so they have a strong incentive to come to work even when ill.  Many outbreaks of Norovirus are traced to this kind of situation.
